data.text:
Programming Languages

Dear reader (especially those from Computer Science, Electronics Engineering and Physics),

Another topic that I will try to write about under the Software section will be about Programming Languages since itâ€™s strictly related to it. ðŸ˜‰

On the last 70 years dozens of computer programming languages were created. Some of them were designed for a specific purpose, others were used in a more general context. Also, many of them are still used today around the world while some of them were abandoned in detriment of more useful and powerful ones.

Just to have an idea how many computer programming languages were invented, a list including the most famous ones and the year when they were created is shown below:

1951 â€“ Regional Assembly Language

1952 â€“ Autocode

1954 â€“ IPL (forerunner to LISP)

1955 â€“ FLOW-MATIC (led to COBOL)

1957 â€“ FORTRAN (First compiler)

1957 â€“ COMTRAN (precursor to COBOL)

1958 â€“ LISP

1958 â€“ ALGOL 58

1959 â€“ FACT (forerunner to COBOL)

1959 â€“ COBOL

1959 â€“ RPG

1962 â€“ APL

1962 â€“ Simula

1962 â€“ SNOBOL

1963 â€“ CPL (forerunner to C)

1964 â€“ Speakeasy (computational environment)

1964 â€“ BASIC

1964 â€“ PL/I

1966 â€“ JOSS

1967 â€“ BCPL (forerunner to C)

1968 â€“ Logo

1969 â€“ B (forerunner to C)

1970 â€“ Pascal

1970 â€“ Forth

1972 â€“ C

1972 â€“ Smalltalk

1972 â€“ Prolog

1973 â€“ ML

1975 â€“ Scheme

1978 â€“ SQL (a query language, later extended)

1980 â€“ C++ (as C with classes, renamed in 1983)

1983 â€“ Ada

1984 â€“ Common Lisp

1984 â€“ MATLAB

1985 â€“ Eiffel

1986 â€“ Objective-C

1986 â€“ Erlang

1987 â€“ Perl

1988 â€“ Tcl

1988 â€“ Wolfram Language

1989 â€“ FL (Backus)

1990 â€“ Haskell

1991 â€“ Python

1991 â€“ Visual Basic

1993 â€“ Ruby

1993 â€“ Lua

1994 â€“ CLOS (part of ANSI Common Lisp)

1995 â€“ Ada 95

1995 â€“ Java

1995 â€“ Delphi (Object Pascal)

1995 â€“ JavaScript

1995 â€“ PHP

1997 â€“ Rebol

1999 â€“ D

2000 â€“ ActionScript

2001 â€“ C#

2003 â€“ Groovy

2003 â€“ Scala

2005 â€“ F#

2006 â€“ Windows PowerShell

2007 â€“ Clojure

2009 â€“ Go

2011 â€“ Dart

2012 â€“ Julia

2014 â€“ Swift

2015 â€“ Rust

Itâ€™s quite a lot, isnâ€™t it? ðŸ™‚

The programming languages cited above that are enhanced in bold and green color are the ones that I intend, initially, to write about in the future. My idea is to explain them in parallel using similar examples or problems to show the main differences between the programming languages (including their advantages and disadvantages).

Therefore, you like to code or even if you never had programmed in your life but would like to, I invite to take a look here from time to time. I do hope that we both can share and learn new things about the wonderful world of programming languages!

If you want to read more about the History of Programming Languages I suggest the Wikipedia link below:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_programming_languages

Thatâ€™s all for now. In the next article related to Programming Languages I will write a little bit more about them (an example: why Eiffel language was created and what applications can benefit from using it?).

Best Regards from Japan.

PS. For those already familiar with programming languages I suggest you to read the cartoon below carefullyâ€¦ ðŸ™‚
